context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For one thing, the Bivens Action comes equipped with a host of legal doctrines, other legal doctrines that offer federal officials a protective shield.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: To win their case, plaintiffs must show, they cannot simply allege, they have to show that the Constitution was in fact violated.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And as Justice Jackson pointed out, the Constitution is not a suicide pact, its provisions are flexible.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The Fourth Amendment for example, forbids unreasonable searches and seizures.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Its warrant requirement often gives way to emergency needs, and what may count as unreasonable in time of peace, may prove necessary in time of war or national security emergency.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They may be changed, but they speak the same language in war as in peace.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The Court should say the same here.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In our view, it should sustain these Bivens Actions.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For these reasons and others set out in our opinion, Justice Ginsburg and I dissent.
